title: What's the difference between “ce”, “ça”, and “cela”, and when do I use each (French)? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Ce” is the originating form. It can be used as a modifier or stand-alone. as a modifier (more specifically a “demonstrative adjective”): Only in the male singular and when not followed by a vowel or h muet. Otherwise it’s “cet” (pronounced “cèt”). Other forms: f.s. “cette”, m./f. pl. “ces” (pronounced “cès”). Its meaning is “this/these <object>”.stand-alone:as a demonstrative pronoun, meaning “this” or “that” ; or:as (3rd person singular neuter) personal pronoun, meaning “it”This can be further made explicit based on whether what is referred to is nearby (“ici” = here) or not (“là” = there). as a modifier (i.e. demonstrative adjective):nearby: “ce/cet/cette/ces” <object>-“ci”, meaning: “this/these <object> here”not nearby: “ce/cet/cette/ces” <object>-“là”, meaning: “that/those <object> there”N.B. The hyphens above mean “ci” and “là” are to be pronounced in one breath with the object that precedes it, even though each (the object and “ci/là”) should still be emphasized separately. stand-alone:as a demonstrative pronounnearby: “ceci”, meaning “this thing here”, (emphasized) “this”not nearby: “cela” (archaic, very rare variant: “celà”) or more informally “ça”, meaning “that thing there”, (emphasized) “that”Finally, when “ce” would be used as a (stand-alone) (3rd person singular neuter) personal pronoun ; and the (main) verb is “aller”, then “ça” is used instead — meaning the same thing, i.e. “it”. (For example: “Ça va?”)
